xxl.core.cursors.sources
Class Enumerator

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Integer>
      xxl.core.cursors.sources.Enumerator
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<Integer>, Cursor<Integer>
public class Enumerator
extends AbstractCursor<Integer>

An enumerator returns an ascending or descending sequence of integer objects within an optional given range. There are three different ways to generate integer objects with an enumerator:

  • Specifying a range, i.e., the start- and end-position are user defined.
  • Specifying only the end-position; start =Bnbsp;0.
  • Specifying no range; start = 0, end = Integer.MAX_VALUE.
In the first case an ascending or a descending sequence can be generated depending on the given start- and end-position.
Note: The start-position of the integer sequence will be returned by the enumerator, but not the end-position! So only the integer elements of the interval [start, end) will be returned by the enumerator.

Example usage (1): 

     Enumerator enumerator = new Enumerator(0, 11);
 
     enumerator.open();
 
     while (enumerator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(enumerator.next());
 
     enumerator.close();
This example prints the numbers 0,...,10 to the output stream.

Example usage (2): 

     enumerator = new Enumerator(10, -1);
 
     enumerator.open();
 
     while (enumerator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(enumerator.next());
 
     enumerator.close();
This example prints the numbers 10,...,0 to the output stream.

Example usage (3): 

     enumerator = new Enumerator(11);
 
     enumerator.open();
 
     while (enumerator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(enumerator.next());
 
     enumerator.close();
This example prints the numbers 0,...,10 to the output stream using only a specified end position.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor

Constructor Detail

Enumerator

public Enumerator(int from,
                  int to)
Creates a new enumerator instance with a specified range, i.e., the start- and an end-position must be defined.

Parameters:
from - start of the returned integer sequence (inclusive).
to - end of the returned integer sequence (exclusive).

Enumerator

public Enumerator(int number)
Creates a new enumerator instance with a user defined end position, i.e., the returned integer sequence starts with 0 and ends with number-1.

Parameters:
number - the end of the returned integer sequence (exclusive).

Enumerator

public Enumerator()
Creates an enumerator instance. The returned integer sequence starts with 0 and ends with Integer.MAX_VALUE-1.

Method Detail

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
Returns:
true if the enumerator has more elements.

nextObject

protected Integer nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the enumerator's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the enumerator to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the iteration again without constructing a new enumerator (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<Integer>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the enumerator.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the enumerator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<Integer>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the enumerator, otrwise false.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
